page.title: 07Warping Drain
page.content: It was constructed in the C17 by the dutchman Vermuyden who came over to show the English how to drain and make use of flooding tide to deposit warp (soil sediment)on the land.The drain is 2.4km long.At the end of the drain is a pumping station built in 1943 and opened in 1944.At the River Trent end on the bank sides there used to be two two large wooden gates which have now been removed.On the drain side one of the openings to the river has been bricked up.Before they used to open the gates at high tide and allow the river to enter the drain and flow out over the land.It would flood up to Amcotts in the north and as far as Ealand and Crowle to the west.When the tide subsided the water was allowed to drain back into the river and the sediment which had been carried by the rushing river remained on the land.
